channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: In India, an App for Chats and for Keeping Secrets
item.description: The Hike instant messaging system lets users filter information to cloak aspects of their social lives from their parents.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI

item.title: Philippine de Rothschild, Wine Nobility, Dies at 80
item.description: The baroness moved from a career as an actress into the lead role in her family business, producing some of the world’s most renowned Bordeaux.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Philippine de Rothschild, known as “the Baroness” in the wine industry, at a 2007 exhibit of her family’s renowned Bordeaux.

item.title: Enrique Zileri, Crusading Publisher in Peru, Dies at 83
item.description: Mr. Zileri was the former publisher of the nation’s top newsmagazine, and was deported several times for his criticisms of the government.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:credit: Alessandro Currarino/El Comercio, via Associated Press

item.title: W.H.O. Removes Team From Sierra Leone After a Medical Worker Contracts Ebola
item.description: A day after announcing a reinvigorated commitment in the country, the World Health Organization said it had removed its Ebola response team after an epidemiologist came down with the virus.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK

item.title: American Fighting for ISIS Is Killed in Syria
item.description: Douglas McAuthur McCain’s death is an early clue for American officials as they try to identify the Americans who have joined ISIS.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: American Journalist, Released by Al Qaeda’s Syrian Branch, Flies Home to His Family
item.description: Peter Theo Curtis, who had been held captive for nearly two years by the Nusra Front, was released after the government of Qatar intervened on his behalf, his family said.
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:description: Peter Theo Curtis arrived in Newark on Tuesday night.

item.title: World Briefing: Tighter Regulation Is Needed for E-Cigarettes, W.H.O. Says
item.description: Governments should have tougher rules for electronic cigarettes until more evidence can be gathered about their risks, the World Health Organization said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: U.N. Helicopter Goes Down, Killing Three in Crew
item.description: A United Nations helicopter carrying cargo in South Sudan crashed on Tuesday, killing three of its four Russian crew members, the United Nations Mission in South Sudan reported.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.S. Mobilizes Allies to Widen Assault on ISIS
item.description: President Obama is nearing a decision to authorize airstrikes and airdrops around Amerli, an Iraqi town that has been under siege by militants for more than two months.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: As the United States begins mobilizing for possible military action in Syria, rebels on Tuesday were in a war-torn area of Aleppo.

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Chinese Workers Abducted
item.description: Kurdish separatists kidnapped three Chinese engineers in an area near a power plant in Turkey’s southeast, a regional government official said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: World Briefing: U.S. Fires on an Iranian Boat
item.description: A United States Coast Guard vessel fired Tuesday on an Iranian boat in the Persian Gulf in what the Defense Department said was a defensive maneuver.
item.dc:creator: By EMMARIE HUETTEMAN

item.title: Putin Talks to Ukrainian Leader as Videos Show Captured Russian Soldiers
item.description: Ukraine released video of what it said were captured Russian soldiers, raising tensions as President Vladimir V. Putin met with his Ukrainian counterpart, Petro O. Poroshenko.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left; Catherine Ashton, the European Union's foreign policy chief, second left; President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, center; and President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, held talks in Minsk, Belarus, about the situation in Ukraine.

item.title: Hard-Line Splinter Group, Galvanized by ISIS, Emerges From Pakistani Taliban
item.description: The new group, known as Jamaat-e-Ahrar, is composed of disaffected Taliban factions from four of the seven tribal districts along the Pakistan border with Afghanistan.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Cease-Fire Extended, but Not on Hamas’s Terms
item.description: The long-term deal, proposed by Egypt, halts the longest, bloodiest battle either side has experienced in years, but without resolving many of the bigger issues underlying the conflict.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A Hamas militant fired a rifle into the air in celebration on Tuesday in Gaza City after the long-term cease-fire was announced.

item.title: Santander Journal: A Banker’s Bold Vision Inspires an Arts Center, and Neighbors’ Doubts
item.description: The Centro Botín, designed by Renzo Piano, is rising in the northern city of Santander, along with complaints that public space is being exploited.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Markel Redondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Centro Botín under construction in Santander, on the northern coast of Spain. The center is scheduled to open next year.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Declare Yom Kippur a U.N. Holiday
item.description: Important United Nations events — even, sometimes, meetings related to Israel — have repeatedly been scheduled on major Jewish holidays.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL S. MARIASCHIN and DAVID J. MICHAELS

item.title: Mayor Klaus Wowereit of Berlin Says He Will Step Down
item.description: Mayor Wowereit, who once described Germany’s capital city as “poor but sexy,” said Tuesday that he would leave the post in December after more than 13 years in the job.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Klaus Wowereit, the mayor of Berlin, announced on Tuesday that he will step down in December.

item.title: Open Source: ISIS Conspiracy Theories Include One That It’s an American Plot
item.description: Supporters of Egypt’s military relied on fabricated quotes said to be from Hillary Rodham Clinton’s memoir to bolster claims that the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria is part of an American plot.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: 1,400 Children in Rotherham, England, Were Sexually Abused, Report Says
item.description: A report commissioned by the local government says that officials over the years had ignored or discounted red flags of the abuse, which dated to 1997.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Afghan Candidate Threatens to Quit the Presidential Race
item.description: Abdullah Abdullah will stop cooperating with an audit of the disputed election results unless his demands are met, a top aide said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah, center, at a rally last week. An aide said Tuesday that the campaign would pull out of an internationally monitored vote audit unless changes to the process were made.

item.title: Fulfilling a Promise, Jewish Center in India Reopens After Terror Attack in 2008
item.description: Rabbis from around the world gathered to reopen the Chabad-Lubavitch center and to remember the six people who were killed there.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rabbis reopened Nariman House, a Jewish center attacked in 2008 during a killing spree by Pakistani gunmen, on Tuesday in Mumbai.

item.title: Betrayal of Yazidis Stokes Iraqi Fears Of Return to 2006 Sectarian Horrors
item.description: Yazidis who fled the violence in northern Iraq were left with a sense of betrayal after Arabs who they thought were friends became supporters of ISIS, or even joined militants.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bahia Mamo, a Yazidi living in a refugee camp in northern Iraq, wept over the kidnapping of a relative by ISIS militants.

item.title: New French Cabinet Sheds Critics and Leaves Austerity Policies in Place
item.description: A day after infighting led to the collapse of the government, Prime Minister Manuel Valls appointed centrist political allies in a bid to crush an open rebellion in his Socialist Party.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France appointed a cabinet of centrist political allies on Tuesday.

item.title: Liberian Doctor Treated With an Experimental Drug Dies From Ebola
item.description: Dr. Abraham Borbor, deputy chief medical doctor at Liberia’s largest hospital, received ZMapp — the same drug given to two infected Americans who survived.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Thailand’s Business in Paid Surrogates May Be Foundering in a Moral Quagmire
item.description: Recent scandals have focused scrutiny on the largely unregulated practice of paid surrogate motherhood, prompting a government crackdown.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Giorgio Taraschi for The New York Times
item.media:description: "There’s nothing wrong with surrogacy — you are helping people who can’t have a baby,” said Pakson Thongda, 42, whose daughter twice sold eggs to a fertility clinic for about $1,000 each time.
